data.title: MAURICE GRAN: As viewers bemoan the state of today's TV comedies, we ask: Who killed the sitcom?
data.meta_description: Fawlty Towers, Porridge, Reggie Perrin - today's TV comedies don't compare to the past's. And the creator of classic show Birds Of A Feather thinks he knows why...
data.text:
As viewers bemoan the state of today's TV comedies, we ask: Who killed the sitcom?

Fawlty Towers, Porridge, Reggie Perrin - today's TV comedies don't compare to the past's. And the creator of classic show Birds of a Feather thinks he knows why...

When I heard that Porridge, one of the greatest sitcoms ever, is to be revived as a stage show I was delighted. Porridge was one of the TV series that inspired my co-writer Laurence Marks and I to try to become comedy writers. And when we made it, our greatest thrill was to meet and work with Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, the creators of Porridge and The Likely Lads.

With Reggie Perrin returning to TV in the figure of Martin Clunes, classic comedy revivals seem to be everywhere. Last night, I stumbled on a brilliant repeat of an old show on ITV3. It was charming, funny, yet extremely moving. It's called Goodnight Sweetheart - and Laurence Marks and I wrote it.

Nostalgic TV does seem to be having a bit of a comeback. Last week, the creators and cast of Fawlty Towers got together to launch a documentary to mark the 30 years since the original series ended on BBC.

John Cleese, with his comedy of pent-up middle-class English anger, was another of our comedy inspirations. Years before Porridge, Laurence and I were the sort of teenagers whose idea of a hysterical night in was sitting around repeating whole Monty Python sketches to each other verbatim.

It was only when we realised we had zero performing talent that we decided to become writers instead. We went on to write Birds Of A Feather and the New Statesman, among others, having survived a baptism of innuendo writing radio shows for Frankie Howerd.

We adored Fawlty Towers when it hit the TV screens, even though we were working at the time on a script set in a rundown seaside hotel. It happens.

Ten years later we met John Cleese, and he was everything we'd hoped he'd be, only taller. He was delighted to discuss all things comedy, but not to answer silly questions like: 'Is there ever going to be another series of Monty Python/Fawlty Towers?'

Now the Fawlty Towers revival question has been asked again. John's response was a crisp 'no' - the cast were too old and tired, he and Connie Booth had found writing the scripts extremely hard work, and you can't turn the clock back.

Prodded by interviewers about today's comedy, John said: 'I don't think comedy writers work as hard as they used to, and I think they may lack experience because I don't think the writing is as good as it used to be.'

There I disagree, though I concur that new writers 'lack experience' - only because it's incredibly hard to gain experience as a comedy writer today.

In the Seventies and Eighties - the years that brought us The Good Life, Only Fools And Horses, Porridge and Rising Damp - there was a sitcom on BBC1 almost every night, and nearly as many on ITV.

If you check this week's TV guides, on the five terrestrial channels you'll find 15 soaps, 13 'reality' programmes, seven property shows, and only four sitcoms. Consequently, new writers - and established ones, too - must compete for a dwindling number of comedy slots.

To get a sitcom on TV now takes incredible perseverance, as well as talent, a great deal of luck and excellent contacts.

Gareth Gwenlan, BBC Head of Comedy for most of the Eighties, once told me in those days there weren't enough good writers to go round. That's why broadcasters lavished enormous amounts of care on infant comedy shows. It was rare to cancel a project after one or even two series; they knew that most comedies take time to get under the audience's skin.

The BBC was especially good at repeating a series to build audiences. Only Fools And Horses, for example, attracted meagre audiences at first. It didn't catch the public's imagination until series three, but went on to become Britain's most popular sitcom ever.

When there were only a few channels, hit shows attracted huge, loyal audiences.

Laurence and I achieved a Christmas Day viewing figure of nearly 18 million for a Birds Of A Feather special. It was trumped on Boxing Day by a Fools And Horses audience of 20 million. Today, even if a writer is lucky enough to get his or her show on screen, if it doesn't achieve a large enough audience within a couple of weeks, it is probably doomed.

The main reason for this collapse is that the economics of television have imploded. In our multi-channel, broadband world, Google earns more through advertising than ITV, which is suffering more cuts than Edward Scissorhands. Meanwhile, Channel 4 and Five contemplate a bizarre shotgun wedding to ensure survival.

The cost of a situation comedy started to look prohibitively high. Stars and scripts are expensive. Even worse, an episode takes a whole week to rehearse and shoot, and you have to build sets and buy costumes.

So instead of sitcoms, the TV companies started making comedy quiz shows. Have I Got News For You paved the way, to be emulated by programmes like Never Mind The Buzzcocks and QI. These are all well made, entertaining and, quite often, funny.

But even quiz shows cost money. Luckily for cash-strapped TV companies, reality television rode to the rescue. For reality television is often comedy in disguise.

Why pay a writer to create a comedy about a bunch of deluded self-seeking young professionals competing for a job with a crusty boss? Why hire a dozen skilled actors to play said characters? Why not just make The Apprentice, and goad some real-life no-hopers into behaving in ways more childish and imbecilic than comedy writers would dare invent? Especially if said no-hopers are doing it for fame rather than wages?

That's not to say that all reality TV is cheap, because we seem to have an infinite appetite for watching 'celebrities' losing their fragile dignities. These personalities - using the word loosely - are richly bribed to inseminate pigs, diet to size zero or venture into the jungle and eat bugs.

Where comedy survives, it often has to adapt to these new, crueller TV norms. Family-oriented sitcoms have been usurped by shows that are 'cooler', crueller, sharper and more cynical. Thus The Office and Extras have been two of the most influential comedies of our digital age, with a high 'squirm factor'.

And so the BBC was seduced into trying to aim most of its comedy at this new young 'hip' audience, while forgetting to entertain the rest of us.

Accordingly, much BBC comedy output has been shunted onto BBC3, a channel aimed at the under-25s, and which many people can't receive on their TVs. Ratings suggest this 'demographic' consists of people who may have more exciting things to do than stay in and watch telly.

Under a new Controller, BBC1 seems to be regaining its appetite for comedy, realising perhaps there is significance in the fact that My Family, an old-fashioned sitcom with big stars and a wildly enthusiastic studio audience, is about to overtake Birds Of A Feather to become the BBC's second longest running sitcom (drat!).

Still, I don't believe the nation will ever again collectively sit down every night to laugh together. It's not that today's writers lack talent or drive, but that we, the audience, are much more fragmented. In 2009 the average household boasts four televisions, three computers, and a couple of DVD players.

It's amazing we ever manage to watch a show as a family. We still do for the big events - the final of X Factor or Deirdre's latest ill-advised wedding on Coronation Street. But most of the time we're doing our own separate things.

And sadly for the comedy writers of tomorrow, we're as likely to be watching a talking dog on YouTube as we are to be tuning in to the latest sitcom on BBC1.
